DOCNAME: CASE OF RUSLAN YAKOVENKO v. UKRAINE
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Lawful arrest or detention;Article 5-1-a - After conviction);Violation of Article 2 of Protocol No. 7 - Right of appeal in criminal matters (Article 2 of Protocol No. 7 - Review of conviction;Review of sentence);Non-pecuniary damage - award (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
JUDGES: Aleš Pejchal;André Potocki;Angelika Nußberger;Ganna Yudkivska;Mark Villiger;Vincent A. De Gaetano
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Bila ORG ( “ the PERSON Tserkva Court ” ) found the applicant guilty of inflicting grievous bodily injuries on a certain Mr N. on DATE . Although this type of crime was punishable with DATE imprisonment , the court considered it possible to apply a more lenient sanction to the applicant . It had regard , in particular , to the fact that he had pleaded guilty and had shown remorse . Accordingly , the court sentenced the applicant to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . It also decided to include in the served part of the applicant ’s sentence the period from DATE to CARDINAL DATE ( DATE and DATE ) , during which he had been detained in the context of another criminal case . Lastly , in fixing the applicant ’s sentence the court had regard to the fact that he “ had spent DATE in [ pre - trial ] detention facilities in which the detention conditions were considerably harsher than in a post - conviction prison , and the previous judgments in respect of him had been quashed ” . No further information is available about the earlier detention of the applicant , the other criminal cases involving him , or the judgments that had been quashed .

CARDINAL . In the operative part of its judgment , ORG also ruled that during his pre - trial detention the applicant should remain in a pre - trial detention centre ( GPE ) as a preventive measure until the judgment became final . It further noted that the judgment was amenable to appeal within DATE of the date of its delivery .

CARDINAL . On DATE the term of the applicant ’s sentence expired , and he asked the PERSON administration to release him . His request was rejected . On DATE the PERSON administration , however , applied to ORG for permission to release the applicant subject to an undertaking not to abscond , given that he had served his prison sentence in full . No reply was received .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer applied once again to the PERSON administration for the applicant ’s immediate release . He submitted , in particular , that there were no grounds for his client ’s continued detention . A copy of that letter was also sent to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the DATE time - limit for lodging an appeal against the judgment of DATE expired and , in the absence of an appeal , it became final .

CARDINAL . On DATE the PERSON administration wrote to the applicant ’s lawyer stating that it could not release the applicant until either the preventive measure in respect of him was changed or the judgment became final . It was noted in the letter that , in any event , it was for ORG to authorise the applicant ’s release .
CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the GPE received the court ’s order to enforce the final judgment and the applicant was released .
